newsitem.title: USA: INSIGHT - Dlr bearish all around, mainly vs yen.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT - Dlr bearish all around, mainly vs yen.

text.p: The dollar outlook is turning increasingly bearish on the charts, mainly against the yen where the loss of 117.60 signals a deeper retreat, possibly all the way to 115.00, chartists said on Wednesday.

"The dollar/yen pullback from the May 4 high led to the test of 117.60, a support level in a bull channel from September," said MCM CurrencyWatch senior analyst Scott Siller. "We lost that, it was taken out today."
Siller said the loss of that key level confirmed a dollar/yen bear flag formation started on May 11 with the loss of 118.25.
In New York on Wednesday, the dollar closed at 117.30/40 versus 118.65/70 at the open and 118.55/65 at the prior close.
Traders reported large sell orders just under 117.80, confirming the market sentiment that a loss of 117.60 would signal a fresh downward trend for dollar/yen.

Chris Turner, a senior technical analyst at the consulting firm I.D.E.A., had predicted that "a move below 117.50 yen would be a nasty one... a break to the downside," echoing Siller's bearish views on dollar/yen.
Siller noted the weekly studies were turning bearish, compounding the negative tone set by the daily charts.

"The weekly studies are taking a strong bearish tone and we could go lower. When the weekly and daily studies are aligned, you have to pay attention to that. It's bearish all around," noted Siller who did not see "any good support until 115.00 yen."

Dollar/mark looked relatively sturdy on the near term, as support at 1.6905/10 held, analysts said. However, bearish divergence on the hourly studies pointed to a possible test of 1.6825/30-mark support down the road, they added.
"1.6825 was the dollar/mark low on Friday, and this gives me the feeling we're going to resume weakness," Siller said.
-- Cable remains bullish and a retest of $1.6550, the high on April 1, cannobe ruled out.
-- Dollar/Swiss is suffering a setback after a good recovery but key 1.43 support appears well protected on the near term.
-- Mark/yen remains weak, but strong support at 68.90 does not seem in jeopardy on the near term.
